frames.input

Class Event

  • java.lang.Object
    • frames.input.Event
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    KeyEvent, MotionEvent, TapEvent

    public class Event
extends java.lang.Object
    The root of all events that are to be handled by an Agent. Every Event encapsulates a Shortcut. Gesture initialization and termination, which may be of the interest of Grabber objects, are reported by fired() and flushed(), respectively.

    The following are the main class specializations: MotionEvent, TapEvent, and KeyEvent. Please refer to their documentation for details.

    If you ever need to define you're own event type, derive from this class; and, optional, declare a shortcut type for your event (overriding the #shortcut()). For details refer to the {@link Shortcut}. If your custom event class defines it's own attributes, its {@link #get()} method should be overridden. Note Event detection/reduction could happened in several different ways. For instance, in the context of Java-based application, it typically takes place when implementing a mouse listener interface. In Processing, it does it when registering at the PApplet the so called mouseEvent and KeyEvent methods. Moreover, the {@link Agent#handleFeed()} provides a callback alternative when none of these mechanisms are available (as it often happens when dealing with specialized, non-default inputGrabber hardware).

      • get

        public Event get()

      • flush

        public Event flush()
        Same as this.get() but sets the flushed() flag to true. Only agents may call this.
        See Also:
        flushed()

      • fire

        public Event fire()
        Same as this.get() but sets the fired() flag to true. Only agents may call this.
        See Also:
        flushed()

      • flushed

        public boolean flushed()
        Returns true if this is a 'flushed' event. Flushed events indicate gesture termination, such as a mouse-release.
        See Also:
        fired()

      • fired

        public boolean fired()
        Returns true if this is a 'fired' event. Fired events indicate gesture activation, such as a mouse-press.
        See Also:
        flushed()

      • shortcut

        public Shortcut shortcut()
        Returns:
        the shortcut encapsulated by this event.
        See Also:

        the time at which the event occurs
